In this study, we investigated the effects of diffirent tungsten additions on the NH3-SCR activities of iron-based catalysts at medium-low temperatures. By comparing the denitration activity, it was found that the catalyst with 20 % tungsten addition (Fe8W2) was determined to have the best denitration activity at medium-low temperatures, and the catalysts’ NO x conversion was more than 80 % in the temperature range of 225–475 °C. Combined with the activity analysis and characterization results, both the WO3-Fe2O3 composite and its entry into the Fe2O3 lattice can effectively promote FeO x dispersion and surface species activation, improving FeO x ’s redox properties. Meanwhile, WO3 and Fe2O3 compound to form FeWO x , and the content of this species is closely related to the medium-low temperature NH3-SCR activity of the catalyst. The results of XPS and H2-TPR indicated that the formation of FeWO x was conducive to the production of more active O species and Fe3+ on the catalyst surface, which may be related to oxygen defects on Fe2O3 and WO3 surfaces caused by Fe-W synergy and the formation of bridged oxygen in Fe x +-On−-W6+. In addition, the NH3-TPD results show that the generation of FeWO x can also significantly increase the number of acid sites on the catalyst surface. Fe-W synergy facilitates the formation of Fe-O-W bonds and uncoordinated saturated Fe x +, creating more Brønsted and Lewis acid sites. This increases the catalyst's capacity to adsorb and activate NH3 species. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Fe-based catalyst Medium-low temperature denitration activity, FeWO x Active O species Surface acid site Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction The NH3-SCR technique offers excellent NO x removal efficiency and stability, and it is widely employed in industry. Catalysts play a significant role in the NH3-SCR process. An appropriate catalyst can lower the NO x reduction temperature in flue gas while improving N2 selectivity [1]. Currently, the widely used commercial SCR catalyst is V2O5-WO3(MoO3)/TiO2, which has a high efficiency for NO x removal. However, V2O5 has some shortcomings such as high toxicity, narrow activity window (300–400 °C) and poor thermal stability, which limit its wide application [2]. Therefore, the creation of an environmentally friendly catalyst with strong denitration activity over a broad active temperature range is a current research focus. The composite oxide catalysts containing Fe, Mn, Ce, Cu, Co and other transition metals showed high NH3-SCR activity. Among these, Fe2O3, as an environmentally friendly substance widely distributed in the earth's crust, offers good redox properties due to its abundant oxygen vacancy and efficient oxygen mobility [3]. A good redox cycle between Fe3+ and Fe2+ can promote NO adsorption activation. The appropriate Fe2+/Fe3+ ratio can generate oxygen vacancy, form unsaturated chemical bonds, and promote the charge imbalance on the catalyst surface, thus improving the denitration performance of the catalyst [4,5]. The excellent NH3-SCR reactivity of Fe-based catalysts has been confirmed and widely studied [6]. Many investigations have confirmed that WO3, a key auxiliary agent of SCR catalysts, promotes the NH3-SCR process [7]. The addition of WO3 to Fe2O3 inhibits NH3 oxidation and promotes NO x adsorption activation, increasing the catalyst's activity and selectivity [8,9]. Xin et al. [10] found that low-crystallized Fe-W composite oxides may greatly enhance the quantity of active O species on the catalyst surface. In Fe-W catalysts [2], there is a synergistic effect between W and Fe to produce Fe-O-W short-range ordered structures. The O atom serves as a bridge in the Fe-O-W structure, while the inserted W-O site stabilizes the Fe species and prevents them from sintering during oxygen-containing high-temperature calcination [11]. After calcining the Fe-W composite oxide at 800 °C for 5 h, the Fe-O-W structure remains on the catalyst's surface as an amorphous coating, improving the catalyst's thermal stability. At the same time, the synergistic effect of Fe-W enables WO3 and Fe2O3 compounds to form on the catalyst surface or enter the Fe2O3 lattice, thus promoting Fe2O3 dispersion and causing the Fe2O3 crystal to become amorphous or low crystallinity. Furthermore, the introduction of appropriate WO3 into Fe-based catalysts is conducive to the formation of M-OH (M = Fe, W) bonds and uncoordinated saturated Fe x+ /W x+ [7,12-14], and increased Brønsted and Lewis acidic sites on the catalytic surface. In addition, the latest studies [15,16] found that the Fe-W synergy improves the oxidation capacity of surface substances through the electron induction effect of Fe x +-On−-W6+ bridged oxygen bonds, inhibits the excessive oxidation of NH3 on FeO x and provides abundant surface reaction acid sites for NH3 adsorption. The active O species, Fe2O3 dispersion, and the amount of acid sites on the surface all influence the denitration efficiency of the Fe-W catalyst at medium-low temperatures. Previous studies have modified the Fe2O3-WO3 catalyst in a variety of ways, including changing the precursor, preparation method, and calcination temperature, to regulate the catalyst's structure and performance, resulting in the Fe-W catalyst with high NO x conversion and N2 selectivity over a wide temperature range [17]. However, the studies on the optimal ratio of Fe-W catalysts and the confirmation of active species are rarely reported. In this paper, we investigated the optimal Fe-W ratio and physicochemical characterization to further investigate the effect of Fe-W synergism on the active species and its mechanism to enhance denitration activity at medium-low temperatures, with the goal of further optimizing catalyst performance and exploring related mechanisms. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation Fe-W composite catalyst was prepared by coprecipitation method. Add a certain amount of (NH4)10H2(W2O7)6 to the deionized water, stir fully until completely dissolved, and then add a certain amount of Fe(NO3)2 in proportion, magnetic stirring to make the two fully mixed. Add ammonia water to the solution drop by drop, adjust to pH > 9, continue stirring until the precipitation is complete, spin evaporation and dry. Fe-W bimetallic oxide catalyst was obtained by continuous calcination at 500 °C for 4 h in Muffle furnace, and was denoted as FeXWY (X and Y are the molar ratios of Fe and W, respectively). 2.2 Activity measurement The same catalyst activity measuring device as described in the literature [18] was used for testing the denitration efficiency of the Fe-W bimetal oxide catalyst after hydrothermal treatment. Firstly, take 0.6 mL sieved catalyst particle (50–60 mesh), heating with N2 at 500 °C for 20 min to decrease the oxide on the catalyst surface. A mixture of flue gas (consisting of [NO]= 500 ppm, [NH3]= 500 ppm, [O2]= 5 vol.%, [H2O]= 5 vol.%, equilibrium gas is N2, experimental airspeed is 60,000 h −1), the concentrations of each gas in the tail gas (excluding water) were measured using a Thermo Scientific infrared (IR) spectrometer (Nicolet iS50, USA). Denitration activity was identified at furnace temperatures of 150, 175, 225, 275, 350, 450, and 550 °C. The catalyst activity was computed using the formula below, and the denitrification activity data was analyzed with Origin mapping software. NO x conversion and N2 selectivity were determined using Eq.1 and Eq.2, respectively. (1) N O x conversion ( % ) = N O x − N O o u t − N O 2 o u t N O i n × 100 (2) N 2 selectivity ( % ) = 1 − N O 2 o u t + 2 N 2 O o u t N O i n − N H 3 i n − N O o u t − N H 3 o u t × 100 NOin and NH3in in the two formulas indicate the concentrations of NO and NH3 at the reactor's inlet. NOout, NO2out, N2Oout, and NH3out are the concentrations of NO, NO2, N2O, and NH3 in tail gas following the reactor. 2.3 Catalyst characterizations The XRD patterns were recorded using an X-ray diffractometer (X‘PERT Pro-MPD, Netherlands) using Cu Kα radiation (0.15418 nm, 40 kV, 40 mA). The data was fitted using Jade 6.5 software. The specific surface area and pore volume were measured using the nitrogen adsorption isothermal technique in an Anton Paar adsorption apparatus (AUTOSORB IQ, USA), followed by the specific surface area and pore size distribution using the BET and BJH formulas. Raman spectra were obtained using a HORIBA Jobin Yvon spectrometer (LabRam HR Evolution, France) using an argon laser at 325 nm as the excitation source. The spectra was captured for 20 s with a resolution of 1 cm−1. TEM examination was carried out using an FEI microscope (Tecnai G2 F20, USA) with a voltage of 200 kV and an energy dispersion spectrometer. XPS was performed using the Shimadzu System (AXIS ULTRA DLD, Japan) with Al Kα as the excitation source. The C1s binding energy location was calibrated to 284.8 eV. H2-TPR and NH3-TPD were measured using an Anton-Paar chemisorption analyzer (CHEMBET, USA). Each sample was purified by N2 at 400 °C for 1 hour and then chilled for further testing. In the H2-TPR experiment, the sample is initially saturated with 10 % H2/N2 at 100 °C before being purified in He until the TCD signal is stable. Pre-treated samples were heated from 100 °C to 800 °C at a rate of 10 °C·min−1, and TCD signals were recorded. For NH3-TPD investigations, samples were saturated in 10 % NH3/He at 100 °C, then pursed in He until the TCD signal was stable. The TCD signal was then recorded by heating to 600 °C at a rate of 10 °C·min−1. 3 Results 3.1 Catalytic activities Fig. 1 depicts the NH3-SCR activity of Fe2O3, WO3, and Fe-W catalysts at temperature ranging from 150 to 550 °C. Fe2O3 and WO3 have limited denitration capability over the temperature range, and Fe2O3 has a negative conversion rate at high temperatures. The denitration efficiency of Fe-W catalysts improved as the Fe/W ratio rose at medium-low temperatures (150 °C-450 °C). The low-temperature activity change rule was Fe8W>Fe5W5> Fe2W8. Thus, the Fe-W composite degree and their ratio are significant in determining the catalyst active species status and denitration performance. When the Fe/W ratio is 8:2, the catalyst's denitration activity is the best, the temperature window is large, and the NO x conversion rate exceeds 80 % between 225 and 475 °C. However, at temperature over 450 °C, the denitration activity of all catalysts dropped, which might be attributed to Fe species’ strong oxidation capacity at high temperatures, which oxidizes NH3 to NO x [19]. In the following study, several characterization approaches will be employed to analyze the structure and surface properties of Fe-W catalyst and investigate its structure-activity connection. The N2 selectivity of the catalysts except Fe2O3 is always high as shown in Fig. 1b. Among the catalysts, Fe8W2 and Fe5W5 exhibit a relatively significant decrease in N2 selectivity at temperatures above 350 °C. The effect of introducing SO2 on the performance of NH3-SCR are also investigated, and the results are shown in Fig. 1(c). The activity of Fe8W2 catalyst only decreased slightly after the introduction of SO2, and the activity of the catalyst was restored after SO2 was turned off. Combined with the above sulfur resistance and stability in the long-time SCR test, it can be seen that FeW catalyst is more suitable for DeNO x of sulfur flue gas. These features make it a promising SCR catalyst which can be applied in medium-low temperature NH3-SCR reaction. 3.2 Textural and structural properties In this study, XRD was employed to characterize the crystal structure of the prepared catalyst, with the findings presented in Fig. 2 . For Fe-W composite catalyst, as the Fe/W ratio increased, the diffraction peak of Fe2O3 gradually decreased until nearly disappeared, and no obvious WO3 diffraction peak was observed in the XRD spectra of Fe8W2 and Fe5W5 catalysts, indicating that the Fe-W composite effect [2] causes Fe2O3 and WO3 to form FeWO x oxide. This significantly increased the dispersion of Fe2O3 and WO3, resulting in amorphous or low-crystallinity Fe2O3 and WO3 crystals. According to XRD characterization, WO3 phase is dominant in Fe2W8, while there is no obvious dominant phase in Fe8W2 and Fe5W5, only Fe2O3 and WO3 phases are more obvious in the former and the latter, respectively. Meanwhile, Fe8W2 and Fe5W5 catalysts have a low-intensity diffraction peak at 2θ: 20–30 °, indicating the presence of low-crystallinity oxides that are too dispersed for XRD to identify [20]. The high dispersion oxide may be the major factor determining catalytic activity at low temperatures. Fig. 3 presents the N2 adsorption and desorption isothermal curves, as well as the pore size distribution of pure Fe2O3 and WO3 materials and Fe-W series catalysts. The N2 adsorption and desorption curves for pure material and Fe-W catalyst are all type Ⅳ, with the H1 hysteresis loop indicating regular and organized mesoporous structures. The specific surface area, pore volume, and pore size of the Fe-W catalyst and the corresponding pure oxide were determined using N2 adsorption and desorption, as shown in Table 1 . Obviously, the Fe/W ratio of catalyst specific surface area, entrance, and the impact of different apertures. Fe2O3 and WO3 have specific surface areas of 8.1 m2·g −1 and 14.2 m2·g −1, respectively. The Fe/W ratio increases the specific surface area and pore volume of the Fe-W catalyst. Fe8W2 catalyst has the greatest specific surface area and pore volume, measuring 69.9 m2·g −1 and 0.174 cm3·g −1, respectively. The above trend is consistent with the XRD data. Fe-W synergy enhances the dispersion of Fe2O3 and WO3, and the resultant tiny oxide particles collect to form a more abundant mesoporous structure, which is primarily responsible for the composite catalyst's increased specific surface area and pore volume [21]. However, Fe2W8 has a smaller specific surface area and pore volume than WO3, measuring 3.9 m2·g −1 and 0.022 cm3·g −1. This is because Fe2W8 failed to generate a good Fe-W synergy, and some Fe species blocked the pores of WO3, which is one of the causes for Fe2W8’s low-temperature activity [22]. According to the SEM image in Fig. 4 , the morphology of Fe2O3 and WO3 is solid spherical particles, instead the Fe-W catalyst is a massive structure with many voids, which is compatible with the physical adsorption results. These findings suggest that the combination of Fe2O3 and WO3 can effectively control the pore shape of the Fe-W catalyst and boost its activity to some extent. The surface structure of the Fe-W catalyst and the pure substance was characterized using Raman spectroscopy, and the findings are presented in Fig. 5 . Fe2O3’s characteristic bands include 209 cm−1, 270 cm−1, 383 cm−1, 482 cm−1, and 582 cm−1 [23], whereas WO3’s characteristic bands are 270 cm−1, 320 cm−1, 715 cm−1, and 810 cm−1 [24-26]. Fe2W8 showed characteristic bands belonging to Fe2O3 at 209 cm−1 and 270 cm−1, and WO3 at 715 cm−1 and 810 cm−1, indicating that WO3 dispersion in the catalyst was relatively poor [27]. In the spectra of Fe5W5 and Fe8W2, the typical bands of WO3 crystals practically vanish, leaving only the characteristic bands of Fe2O3 crystals at 209 cm−1 and 270 cm−1, with much reduced signal strength. This suggests that raising the Fe/W ratio can accelerate the synergy of Fe2O3 and WO3 on the catalyst surface [28], resulting in increased dispersion of the two compounds. There is a certain difference with XRD characterization, Fe8W2 and Fe5W5 are obviously dominated by Fe2O3 phase, Fe2W8 is still dominated by WO3 phase. 3.3 States of surface active species The surface chemical composition and species valence state of the Fe-W catalyst were investigated by XPS. Fig. 6 (a), (b), and (c) show the XPS energy spectra of Fe 2p, W 4f, and O 1 s, respectively, with the spectra of Fe 2p and O 1 s as sub-peak fitted. Fig. 6(a) shows that the distinctive bands observed at 710.8 eV and 723.5 eV are attributed to Fe2+, while those detected at 712.9 eV and 726.3 eV belong to Fe3+ [29,30]. The Fe3+/(Fe2++Fe3+) values calculated with the XPS energy spectrum area are as follows: Fe8W2 (54 %), Fe5W5 (42 %), and Fe2W8 (41 %), all of them consistent with the catalyst's activity at medium-low temperatures. According to literature studies [19], the Fe3+ ratio influences the redox capacity, NO x /NH3 adsorption activation, and acid site of the catalyst, therefore correctly raising the Fe3+ ratio would assist improve the catalytic performance of NH3-SCR. Since the medium-low temperature SCR processes generally follow the Langmuir-Hinshelwood reaction mechanism [31,32], an appropriate increase in the proportion of Fe3+ is conducive to increasing the catalyst's adsorption capacity for NH3, which is then oxidized to -NH2 [33-35], an important intermediate substance in the SCR reaction. It can react with NO activation products (NO2 − and NO3 −) to produce an intermediate substance, which can subsequently be degraded into N2 and H2O. However, increasing the Fe3+ ratio improves the catalyst's oxidation capacity, forcing the oxidation of NH3 into NO x and lowering the catalyst's high-temperature activity. At the same time, Fe3+ can provide Lewis acid sites, enhancing the acidity and low-temperature activity of the catalyst [19]. Furthermore, the increasing percentage of Fe3+ is linked to the production of FeWO x and the electrical interaction between WO3 and Fe2O3 [10,20,36]. The electronegativity of Fe and W is 1.83 and 2.36, respectively. In a Fe-W catalyst, W has a stronger electron absorption capacity, which allows the electron cloud around Fe to shift to W, boosting the formation of Fe3+. The coexistence of Fe2+ and Fe3+ can result in imbalanced and unsaturated chemical bonds, increasing the quantity of surface chemisorption oxygen to a certain extent [37,38]. Fig. 6(c) shows how the XPS for O 1 s is fitted to two peaks. The O 1 s binding energy bands at 531.3–532.9 eV and 529.6–530.5 eV belong to surface oxygen (Oα) and lattice oxygen (Oβ) in chemisorbed adsorption, respectively [39]. Surface oxygen (Oα) has excellent migration and oxidation capacity, making it a major element in NO oxidation to NO2. During denitration, NO can combine with the active site's Oα to produce NO2 or nitrate, boosting the SCR reaction's medium-temperature activity [29,40]. The Oα/(Oα+Oβ) ratios of Fe2W8, Fe5W5, and Fe8W2 were 9 %, 13 %, and 24 %, respectively. Among the various Fe-W ratios, Fe8W2 has the highest surface chemisorbed oxygen content, which is due to the strong interaction of Fe-W in the Fe8W2 catalyst. And the FeWO x generated by it can promote the formation of active O species on the surface, thereby improving the catalyst's NH3-SCR reaction activity at medium-low temperatures. The redox performance of the Fe-W catalyst is a crucial factor in determining the catalytic activity of NH3-SCR, as seen by the H2-TPR curve in Fig. 7 . The redox performance of the Fe-W catalyst is a crucial factor in determining the catalytic activity of NH3-SCR, as seen by the H2-TPR curve in Fig. 7. The low-temperature reduction peaks (red) of Fe2O3 and WO3 are ascribed to the reduction of Fe2O3→ Fe3O4 and WO3→ W2O5, respectively, whilst the high-temperature reduction peaks (blue) of both are related to the reduction of Fe3O4→ FeO [23] and W2O5→ WO2 [41].Compared with Fe2O3 and WO3, the reduction peak area of Fe-W catalyst rises drastically, which can be attributed to Fe-W synergy. Based on the references [21], we believe that the low-temperature reduction peak (red) of the Fe-W catalyst includes both the reduction of related species in the aforementioned pure substances and the co-reduction of FeWO x . Similarly, the high-temperature reduction peak (blue) of the Fe-W catalyst is attributed to the same low-temperature reduction peak as seen above. An adequate Fe/W ratio promotes the development of FeWO x composite oxides, and Fe-W interaction in FeWO x can improve catalyst particle dispersion, boosting the rise of low-temperature reduction species. The Fe/W ratio increases, as does the catalyst's low-temperature reduction area. However, the change in peak area at high temperatures is opposite, which can be attributed to a drop in FeWO x and Fe-W interactions in the catalyst, resulting in an increase in catalyst particles and a decrease in species at high temperatures. For Fe-W catalysts [21,36], the strong interaction between Fe and W can generate more surface vacancies and -OH, which is conducive to the formation of high density W-type holes and Fe type electrons on Fe2O3, while Fe's high electron density promotes O adsorption and activation. It has been reported that the formation of Fe x +-On−-W6+ bridged oxygen on the catalyst surface could result in the enhancement of oxidation ability of the surface FeO x , and these types of surface iron as well as dispersed FeO x have strong redox properties [36]. The active species formed by the Fe-W interaction contribute significantly to the Fe-W catalyst's high redox performance [17]. NH3 adsorption and activation are critical processes of the NH3-SCR reaction. To explore the effect of changing the Fe/W ratio on the acidity of the Fe-W catalyst, NH3-TPD characterization was performed on the catalyst, with the findings displayed in Fig. 8 . The NH3-TPD spectra of pure substances and Fe-W catalysts can be fitted to three NH3 desorption peaks: the low-temperature desorption peak (I) at 250 °C is attributed to NH3 species adsorbed at the weak acid site, and the medium-temperature desorption peak (II) at 250–400 °C is attributed to NH3 species adsorbed at the medium-strong acid site. The high-temperature desorption peak (III) at 400 °C is caused by NH3 species adsorbed at the strong acid site [42,43]. The peak area of NH3-TPD was calculated to figure out the number of acid sites in the sample, as shown in Table 2 . Total acid sites are in the following order: Fe8W2>Fe5W5>WO3>Fe2W8>Fe2O3. Based on the above characterization results, it is clear that the variation law of the number of acid sites in the sample is mainly consistent with the degree of Fe-W synergy, implying that Fe-W synergy can promote the rise of acid sites. The literature indicates [44] that Lewis acid sites on Fe-W catalysts are primarily obtained from Fe x +/W x + in composite oxides, and Brønsted acid sites are mainly formed from W = O, W-O-W, Fe-O-W and other species. Both the content of medium and strong acids increased with the increase of Fe-W ratio, and the central temperature of desorption peak increased to a certain extent compared with WO3, mainly because Fe-W synergy is conducive to the formation of M-OH (M = Fe, W) bond and uncoordinated saturated Fe x +/W x +. The production of FeWO x creates several surface Brønsted and Lewis acid sites, leading to the generation of activated NH3 and -NH2 [2,21,36,45,46], facilitating NH3-SCR capture. 4 Discussion The surface structure, status of active species, and redox capacity of Fe-W catalyst are the primary factors influencing its activity at low temperatures. In Fe-W composite catalysts with a high Fe/W ratio (Fe5W5 and Fe8W2 catalysts), Fe and W interact strongly. Since the radius of the W6+ ion (0.060 nm) and the Fe3+ ion (0.064 nm) are close together, they may enter each other's lattice, leading to lattice distortion and FeWO x composite oxides, while the defect sites and heterophase interfaces can inhibit the sintering aggregation of WO3 and Fe2O3 during the calcination process [47]. Defect sites and heterophase interfaces can significantly raise Fe2O3 and WO3 dispersion while boosting the catalyst's specific surface area and pore volume, as demonstrated by XRD, SEM, and BET studies. It has been reported that [17,48] lattice distortion and the creation of defect sites promote the creation of surface active O species. As Fe (1.83) has a lower electronegativity than W (2.36), the electron cloud around Fe x + is moved to W6+ through the Fe x +-On−-W6+ bridging oxygen bond, leaving an increase in Fe3+ concentration on the catalyst surface. Furthermore, the Fe-W composite generating Fe x +-On−-W6+ oxygen species has a substantial number of bridge structures, and the relative oxygen species typically has stronger oxidation–reduction properties and NO oxidation activity [49]. Increased Fe-W synergy degree leads to higher surface Fe3+ and active Oα concentrations in the catalyst, judging by XPS data. Combined with the H2-TPR results, it is clear that as the degree of Fe-W synergy in the catalyst increases, so does the area of the low-temperature reduction peak, which is predominantly owing to changes in the number of Fe3+ ions on the surface, Fe x +-On−-W6+ bridged oxygen bonds, and Fe-W species dispersion. Fe3+ ions and Fe x +-On−-W6+ bridging oxygen play an essential part in the NH3-SCR reaction at medium and low temperatures, and enhancing the amount of each can assist improve the SCR performance of the Fe-W catalyst. The surface acidity of a catalyst is another crucial factor that impacts its SCR efficiency. Lewis acid sites on Fe-W catalysts are mostly formed from unsaturated Fe x +/W x +, while Brønsted acid sites are primarily obtained from W = O, W-O-W, and Fe-O-W species, which can interact with NH3/H2O to transform into Brønsted acid sites [50]. On the one hand, when Fe-W synergy develops, the Fe3+ ratio and Fe2+ unsaturated rises, resulting in an increase in Lewis acid sites. On the other hand, it promotes the creation of Fe-O-W species, which is the main reason for an upsurge in the total acid content of Fe5W5 and Fe8W2. The NH3-TPD results show a correlation between the number of acid sites in the sample and the degree of Fe-W synergy. This suggests that Fe-W synergy can effectively enhance the creation of Lewis and Brønsted acid sites. In summary, catalysts with appropriate acidity and redox properties have higher NH3-SCR activity [51]. The strong interaction between Fe and W leads to increased Fe3+ ions, active surface oxygen, and acid sites, which are the major active sites of the NH3-SCR process. Fig. 9 illustrates the generating mechanism. 5 Conclusion By adjusting the Fe/W ratio, we got differed dispersions and synergy degrees of Fe and W species in the two mixed oxides. The optimum Fe/W ratio increases metal oxide dispersion and interaction, resulting in more than 80 % NO x conversion throughout a wide temperature range (225–475 °C). The electron redistribution effect arising from the Fe-W synergy lead to the increase in the amounts of Fe3+ ions and active surface oxygen species, which facilitate the medium-low temperature NH3-SCR activity via the Fe x +-On−-W6+ bridged oxygen bonds. Electron transfer from Fe x + to W6+ also increases the amount of Lewis acid sites formed from unsaturated Fe x +. The Fe-W catalyst's Fe-O-W bond develops a larger Brønsted acid site as well. These acid sites are also essential determinants in the adsorption/activation of NH3 species and the enhancement of NH3-SCR activity. coredata.dc:description: In this study, we investigated the effects of diffirent tungsten additions on the NH3-SCR activities of iron-based catalysts at medium-low temperatures. By comparing the denitration activity, it was found that the catalyst with 20 % tungsten addition (Fe8W2) was determined to have the best denitration activity at medium-low temperatures, and the catalysts’ NO x conversion was more than 80 % in the temperature range of 225–475 °C. Combined with the activity analysis and characterization results, both the WO3-Fe2O3 composite and its entry into the Fe2O3 lattice can effectively promote FeO x dispersion and surface species activation, improving FeO x ’s redox properties. Meanwhile, WO3 and Fe2O3 compound to form FeWO x , and the content of this species is closely related to the medium-low temperature NH3-SCR activity of the catalyst. The results of XPS and H2-TPR indicated that the formation of FeWO x was conducive to the production of more active O species and Fe3+ on the catalyst surface, which may be related to oxygen defects on Fe2O3 and WO3 surfaces caused by Fe-W synergy and the formation of bridged oxygen in Fe x +-On−-W6+. In addition, the NH3-TPD results show that the generation of FeWO x can also significantly increase the number of acid sites on the catalyst surface. Fe-W synergy facilitates the formation of Fe-O-W bonds and uncoordinated saturated Fe x +, creating more Brønsted and Lewis acid sites. This increases the catalyst's capacity to adsorb and activate NH3 species.
